Rarely; not often; not frequently; Rare; infrequent.
adv

seldomness
Rareness.
n

seldseen
Seldom seen.
adj

seldshewn
Rarely shown or exhibited.
adj

select
Taken from a number by preferance; picked out as more valuable or exellent than others; of special value or exellence; nicely chosen; selected; choice; To choose and take from a number; to take by preference from among others; to pick out; to cull; as to select the best authors for perusal.
adj

selectedly
With care and selection.
adv

selection
The act of selecting or the state of being selected; choice by preference; That which is selected; a collection of things chosen; as a choice selection of books.
n

selective
Selecting; tending to select.
adj

selectman
One of a board of town officers chosen annually in the New England States to transact the general public business of the town and have a kind of executive authority. The number is usually from three to seven in each town.
n

selectness
The quality or state of being select.
n

selector
One who selects.
n

selenate
A salt of selenic acid; -- formerly called also seleniate.
n

selenhydric
Of pertaining to or designating hydrogen selenide H2Se regarded as an acid analogous to sulphydric acid.
adj

selenic
Of or pertaining to selenium; derived from or containing selenium; specifically designating those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with selenious compounds.
adj

selenide
A binary compound of selenium or a compound regarded as binary; as ethyl selenide.
n

seleniferous
Containing or impregnated with selenium; as seleniferous pyrites.
adj

selenio-
A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting the presence of selenium or its compounds; as selenio-phosphate a phosphate having selenium in place of all or a part of the oxygen.
misc

selenious
Of pertaining to or containing selenium; specifically designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valence as contrasted with selenic compounds.
adj

selenite
A salt of selenious acid; A variety of gypsum occuring in transparent crystals or crystalline masses.
n

selenitic
Of or pertaining to selenite; resembling or containing selenite.
adj

selenium
A nonmetallic element of the sulphur group of atomic number 34 analogous to sulphur in its compounds. It is found in small quantities with sulphur and some sulphur ores and obtained in the free state as a dark reddish powder or crystalline mass or as a dark metallic-looking substance. It exhibits under the action of light a remarkable variation in electric conductivity and is used in certain electric apparatus. Symbol Se. Atomic weight 78.96.
n

seleniuret
A selenide.
n

seleniureted
Combined with selenium as in a selenide; as seleniureted hydrogen.
adj

selenocentric
As seen or estimated from the center of the moon; with the moon central.
adj

selenograph
A picture or delineation of the moon's surface or of any part of it.
n

selenographer
One skilled in selenography.
n

selenographic
Of or pertaining to selenography.
adj

selenographist
A selenographer.
n

selenography
The science that treats of the physical features of the moon; -- corresponding to physical geography in respect to the earth.
n

selenology
That branch of astronomy which treats of the moon.
n

selenonium
A hypothetical radical of selenium analogous to sulphonium.
n

self
Same; particular; very; identical; Having its own or a single nature or character as in color composition etc. without addition or change; unmixed; as a self bow one made from a single piece of wood; self flower or plant one which is wholly of one color; self-colored; The individual as the object of his own reflective consciousness; the man viewed by his own cognition as the subject of all his mental phenomena the agent in his own activities the subject of his own feelings and the possessor of capacities and character; a person as a distinct individual; a being regarded as having personality; Hence personal interest or love of private interest; selfishness; as self is his whole aim; Personification; embodiment.
adj

self-abased
Humbled by consciousness of inferiority unworthiness guilt or shame.
adj

self-abasement
Degradation of one's self by one's own act; Humiliation or abasement proceeding from consciousness of inferiority guilt or shame.
n

self-abasing
Lowering or humbling one's self.
adj

self-abhorrence
Abhorrence of one's self.
n

self-abnegation
Self-denial; self-renunciation; self-sacrifice.
n

self-abuse
The abuse of one's own self powers or faculties; Self-deception; delusion; Masturbation; onanism; self-pollution.
n

self-accused
Accused by one's self or by one's conscience.
adj

self-acting
Acting of or by one's self or by itself; -- said especially of a machine or mechanism which is made to perform of or for itself what is usually done by human agency; automatic; as a self-acting feed apparatus; a self-acting mule; a self-acting press.
adj

self-action
Action by or originating in one's self or itself.
n

self-active
Acting of one's self or of itself; acting without depending on other agents.
adj

self-activity
The quality or state of being self-active; self-action.
n

self-adjusting
Capable of assuming a desired position or condition with relation to other parts under varying circumstances without requiring to be adjusted by hand; -- said of a piece in machinery.
adj

self-admiration
Admiration of one's self.
n

self-affairs
One's own affairs; one's private business.
n

self-affrighted
Frightened at or by one's self.
adj

self-aggrandizement

n

self-annihilated

adj

n

self-applause

Applying to or by one's self.

adj

asserting one's self or one's own rights or claims; hence putting one's self forward in a confident or assuming manner.

self-assertion

n

self-assertive

adj

adj

n

self-born

adj

adj

self-centering
Centering in one's self.
adj

self-centration
The quality or state of being self-centered.
n

self-charity

n

self-color
A color not mixed or variegated.
n

self-colored
Being of a single color; -- applied to flowers animals and textile fabrics.
adj

self-command
Control over one's own feelings temper etc.; self-control.
n

self-commune

n

adj

self-conjugate
Having the two things that are conjugate parts of the same figure; as self-conjugate triangles.
adj

self-conscious
Conscious of one's acts or state as belonging to or originating in one's self; Conscious of one's self as an object of the observation of others; as the speaker was too self-conscious.
adj

self-consciousness
The quality or state of being self-conscious.
n

self-considering
Considering in one's own mind; deliberating.
adj

self-consistency
The quality or state of being self-consistent.
n

self-consistent
Consistent with one's self or with itself; not deviation from the ordinary standard by which the conduct is guided; logically consistent throughout; having each part consistent with the rest.
adj

self-consuming
Consuming one's self or itself.
adj

self-contained
Having self-control; reserved; uncommunicative; wholly engrossed in one's self; Having all the essential working parts connected by a bedplate or framework or contained in a case etc. so that mutual relations of the parts do not depend upon fastening outside of the machine itself.
adj

self-contained-underwater-breathing-apparatus
A portable device to allow divers to breathe while under water consisting of one or two tanks of compressed air which are strapped onto the back of the diver and are connected by tubing to a mouthpiece through which the diver receives the air from the tanks at rate adjustable by a valve; -- called also SCUBA SCUBA gear or SCUBA apparatus.
n

self-contradiction
The act of contradicting one's self or itself; repugnancy in conceptions or in terms; a proposition consisting of two members one of which contradicts the other; as to be and not to be at the same time is a self-contradiction.
n

self-contradictory
Contradicting one's self or itself.
adj

self-control
Control of one's self; restraint exercised over one's self; self-command.
n

self-convicted
Convicted by one's own consciousness knowledge avowal or acts.
adj

self-conviction
The act of convicting one's self or the state of being self-convicted.
n

self-created
Created by one's self; not formed or constituted by another.
adj

self-evident
Evident without proof or reasoning; producing certainty or conviction upon a bare presentation to the mind; as a self-evident proposition or truth.
adj

self-evolution
Evolution of one's self; development by inherent quality or power.
n

self-exaltation
The act of exalting one's self or the state of being so exalted.
n

self-examinant
One who examines himself; one given to self-examination.
n

self-examination
An examination into one's own state conduct and motives particularly in regard to religious feelings and duties.
n

self-excite
To energize or excite (the field magnets of a dynamo) by induction from the residual magnetism of its cores leading all or a part of the current thus produced through the field-magnet coils.
v

self-existence
Inherent existence; existence possessed by virtue of a being's own nature and independent of any other being or cause; -- an attribute peculiar to God.
n

self-existent
Existing of or by himself independent of any other being or cause; -- as God is the only self-existent being.
adj

self-explaining
Explaining itself; capable of being understood without explanation.
adj

self-exposure
The act of exposing one's self; the state of being so exposed.
n

self-fertilization
The fertilization of a flower by pollen from the same flower and without outer aid; autogamy.
n

self-fertilized
Fertilized by pollen from the same flower.
adj

self-glorious
Springing from vainglory or vanity; vain; boastful.
adj

self-government
The act of governing one's self or the state of being governed by one's self; self-control; self-command; Hence government of a community state or nation by the joint action of the mass of people constituting such a civil body; also the state of being so governed; democratic government; democracy.
n

self-gratulation
Gratulation of one's self.
n

self-hardening
Designating or pert. to any of various steels that harden when heated to above a red heat and cooled in air usually in a blast of cold air with moderate rapidity without quenching. Such steels are alloys of iron and carbon with manganese tungsten and manganese chromium molybdenum and manganese etc. They are chiefly used as high-speed steels.
adj

self-heal
A blue-flowered labiate plant (Brunella vulgaris); the healall.
n

self-healing
Having the power or property of healing itself.
adj

self-help
The act of aiding one's self without depending on the aid of others; The right or fact of redressing or preventing wrongs by one's own action without recourse to legal proceedings as in self-defense distress abatement of a nuisance etc; developing one's capabilities or solving one's own problems especially psychological problems without the assistance of a professional by independent study or by association with other individuals having similar interests; of pertaining to or useful for the process of developing one's capabilities or solving one's problems; as self-help books on writing for profit.
n

self-homicide
The act of killing one's self; suicide.
n

selfhood
Existence as a separate self or independent person; conscious personality; individuality.
n

self-ignorance
Ignorance of one's own character powers and limitations.
n

self-ignorant
Ignorant of one's self.
adj

self-imparting
Imparting by one's own or by its own powers and will.
adj

self-importance
An exaggerated estimate of one's own importance or merit esp. as manifested by the conduct or manners; self-conceit.
n

self-important
Having or manifesting an exaggerated idea of one's own importance or merit.
adj

self-imposed
Voluntarily taken on one's self; as self-imposed tasks.
adj

self-imposture
Imposture practiced on one's self; self-deceit.
n

self-indignation
Indignation at one's own character or actions.
n

self-induction
Induction in a circuit due to the action of one portion of a current upon an adjacent portion during periods of varying current strength. The nature of the induction is such as to oppose the action which produces it.
n

self-indulgence
Indulgence of one's appetites desires or inclinations; -- the opposite of self-restraint and self-denial.
n

self-indulgent
Indulging one's appetites desires etc. freely.
adj

self-interest
Private interest; the interest or advantage of one's self.
n

self-interested
Particularly concerned for one's own interest or happiness.
adj

self-involution
Involution in one's self; hence abstraction of thought; reverie.
n

selfish
Caring supremely or unduly for one's self; regarding one's own comfort advantage etc. in disregard or at the expense of those of others; Believing or teaching that the chief motives of human action are derived from love of self.
adj

selfishly
In a selfish manner; with regard to private interest only or chiefly.
adv

selfishness
The quality or state of being selfish; exclusive regard to one's own interest or happiness; that supreme self-love or self-preference which leads a person to direct his purposes to the advancement of his own interest power or happiness without regarding those of others.
n

selfism
Concentration of one's interests on one's self; self-love; selfishness.
n

selfist
A selfish person.
n

self-justifier
One who excuses or justifies himself.
n

self-kindled
Kindled of itself or without extraneous aid or power.
adj

adj

Knowledge of one's self or of one's own character powers limitations etc.
n

selfless
Having no regard to self; unselfish.
adj

selflessness
Quality or state of being selfless.
n

self-life
Life for one's self; living solely or chiefly for one's own pleasure or good.
n

self-love

n

Possessing in itself the property of emitting light.
adj

adj

self-registering
Registering itself; -- said of any instrument so contrived as to record its own indications of phenomena whether continuously or at stated times as at the maxima and minima of variations; as a self-registering anemometer or barometer.

The quality or state of being self-repelling.
n

self-repelling
Made up of parts as molecules or atoms which mutually repel each other; as gases are self-repelling.
adj

self-repetition
Repetition of one's self or of one's acts; the saying or doing what one has already said or done.
n

n

self-reproached

adj

n

adj

adj

self-reprovingly

adv

self-repugnant
Self-contradictory; inconsistent.
adj

self-repulsive
Self-repelling.
adj

self-respect
Respect for one's self; regard for one's character; laudable self-esteem.
n

self-restrained
Restrained by one's self or itself; restrained by one's own power or will.
adj

self-restraint
Restraint over one's self; self-control; self-command.
n

self-reverence
A reverent respect for one's self.
n

self-righteous
Righteous in one's own esteem; pharisaic.
adj

self-righteousness
The quality or state of being self-righteous; pharisaism.
n

self-sacrifice
The act of sacrificing one's self or one's interest for others; self-devotion.
n

self-sacrificing
Yielding up one's own interest feelings etc; sacrificing one's self.
adj

selfsame
Precisely the same; the very same; identical.
adj

self-satisfaction
The quality or state of being self-satisfied.
n

self-satisfied
Satisfied with one's self or one's actions; self-complacent.
adj

self-satisfying
Giving satisfaction to one's self.
adj

self-seeker
One who seeks only his own interest advantage or pleasure.
n

self-seeking
Seeking one's own interest or happiness; selfish; The act or habit of seeking one's own interest or happiness; selfishness.
adj

self-slaughter
Suicide.
n

self-starter
A mechanism (usually one operated by electricity compressed air a spring or an explosive gas) attached to an internal-combustion engine as on an automobile and used as a means of starting the engine without cranking it by hand; -- called also a starter.
n

self-sufficiency
The quality or state of being self-sufficient.
n

self-sufficient
Sufficient for one's self without external aid or cooperation; Having an overweening confidence in one's own abilities or worth; hence haughty; overbearing.
adj

self-sufficing
Sufficing for one's self or for itself without needing external aid; self-sufficient.
adj

self-suspended
Suspended by one's self or by itself; balanced.
adj

self-suspicious
Suspicious or distrustful of one's self.
adj

self-taught
Taught by one's own efforts.
adj

self-tormentor
One who torments himself.
n

self-torture
The act of inflicting pain on one's self; pain inflicted on one's self.
n

self-trust
Faith in one's self; self-reliance.
n

self-uned
One with itself; separate from others.
adj

self-view
A view of one's self; specifically carefulness or regard for one's own interests.
n

self-will
One's own will esp. when opposed to that of others; obstinacy.
n

self-willed
Governed by one's own will; not yielding to the wishes of others; obstinate.
adj

self-willedness
Obstinacy.
n

self-worship
The idolizing of one's self; immoderate self-conceit.
n

self-wrong
Wrong done by a person to himself.
n

selion
A short piece of land in arable ridges and furrows of uncertain quantity; also a ridge of land lying between two furrows.
n

seljuckian
A member of the family of Seljuk; an adherent of that family or subject of its government;.
n

seljukian
Of or pertaining to Seljuk a Tartar chief who embraced Mohammedanism and began the subjection of Western Asia to that faith and rule; of or pertaining to the dynasty founded by him or the empire maintained by his descendants from the 10th to the 13th century.
adj

sell
Self; A sill; A cell; a house; A saddle for a horse; A throne or lofty seat; To transfer to another for an equivalent; to give up for a valuable consideration; to dispose of in return for something especially for money. It is the correlative of buy; To make a matter of bargain and sale of; to accept a price or reward for as for a breach of duty trust or the like; to betray; To impose upon; to trick; to deceive; to make a fool of; to cheat; To practice selling commodities; To be sold; as corn sells at a good price; An imposition; a cheat; a hoax.
n

sellanders
See Sallenders.
n

seller
One who sells.
n

selters-water
A mineral water from Sellers in the district of Nassan Germany containing much free carbonic acid.
misc

seltzer-water
See Selters water. - The fluid which descends from the clouds in rain and which forms rivers lakes seas etc; A body of water standing or flowing; a lake river or other collection of water; Any liquid secretion humor or the like resembling water; esp. the urine; A solution in water of a gaseous or readily volatile substance; as ammonia water; The limpidity and luster of a precious stone especially a diamond; as a diamond of the first water that is perfectly pure and transparent. Hence of the first water that is of the first excellence; A wavy lustrous pattern or decoration such as is imparted to linen silk metals etc. See Water v. t. 3 Damask v. t. and Damaskeen; An addition to the shares representing the capital of a stock company so that the aggregate par value of the shares is increased while their value for investment is diminished or �diluted.�; To wet or supply with water; to moisten; to overflow with water; to irrigate; as to water land; to water flowers; To supply with water for drink; to cause or allow to drink; as to water cattle and horses; To wet and calender as cloth so as to impart to it a lustrous appearance in wavy lines; to diversify with wavelike lines; as to water silk. Cf. Water n. 6; To add water to (anything) thereby extending the quantity or bulk while reducing the strength or quality; to extend; to dilute; to weaken; To shed secrete or fill with water or liquid matter; as his eyes began to water; To get or take in water; as the ship put into port to water.
misc

seltzo-gene
A gazogene.
n

selvage
The edge of cloth which is woven in such a manner as to prevent raveling; The edge plate of a lock through which the bolt passes; A layer of clay or decomposed rock along the wall of a vein. See Gouge n. 4.
n

selvaged
Having a selvage.
adj

selvagee
A skein or hank of rope yarns wound round with yarns or marline -- used for stoppers straps etc.
n

selve
Self; same.
adj

selves
pl. of Self.
n

sely
Silly.
adj

semaeostomata
A division of Discophora having large free mouth lobes. It includes Aurelia and Pelagia. Called also Semeostoma. See Illustr. under Discophora and Medusa.
n

semantic
pertaining to the meanings of words; of or pertaining to semantics.
n

semantics
the study of the meanings of words and of the sense development of words; -- formerly called semasiology; a doctrine and philosophical approach to language and its relationship to thought and behavior developed by Alfred Korzybski (1879-1950) which holds that the capacity to express ideas and thereby improve one's interaction with others and one's environment is enhanced by training in the more critical use of words and other symbols; -- also called general semantics; the meanings of words as they are used to achieve an effect; especially the multiple meanings of words or the multiplicity of words having the same meaning; -- used in referring to the confusion that can be caused (intentionally or unintentionally) by multiple meanings; as there's no real difference it's only a matter of semantics.
n

semaphore
A signal telegraph; an apparatus for giving signals by the disposition of lanterns flags oscillating arms etc.
n

semaphoric
Of or pertaining to a semaphore or semaphores; telegraphic.
adj

semaphorically
By means of a semaphore.
adv

semaphorist
One who manages or operates a semaphore.
n

semasiology
The science of meanings or sense development (of words); the explanation of the development and changes of the meanings of words; -- more commonly referred to as semantics.
n

sematic
Significant; ominous; serving as a warning of danger; -- applied esp. to the warning colors or forms of certain animals.
adj

sematology
The doctrine of signs as the expression of thought or reasoning; the science of indicating thought by signs.
n

sematrope
An instrument for signaling by reflecting the rays of the sun in different directions.
n

semblable
Like; similar; resembling; Likeness; representation.
adj

semblably
In like manner.
adv

semblance
Seeming; appearance; show; figure; form; Likeness; resemblance actual or apparent; similitude; as the semblance of worth; semblance of virtue.
n

semblant
Like; resembling; Seeming rather than real; apparent; Show; appearance; figure; semblance; The face.
adj

semblative
Resembling.
adj

semble
To imitate; to make a representation or likeness; It seems; -- chiefly used impersonally in reports and judgments to express an opinion in reference to the law on some point not necessary to be decided and not intended to be definitely settled in the cause; Like; resembling.
v

sembling
The practice of attracting the males of Lepidoptera or other insects by exposing the female confined in a cage.
n

seme
A linguistic sign; A basic component of meaning of a morpheme especially one which cannot be decomposed into more basic components; a primitive concept; Sprinkled or sown; -- said of field or a charge when strewed or covered with small charges.
n

semeiography
A description of the signs of disease.
n

semeiological
Of or pertaining to the science of signs or the systematic use of signs; as a semeiological classification of the signs or symptoms of disease; a semeiological arrangement of signs used as signals.
adj

semeiology
The study of signs as an element of communication; the analysis of systems of communication; -- also called semiotics.
n

semeiotic
Relating to signs or indications; pertaining to the language of signs or to language generally as indicating thought; Of or pertaining to the signs or symptoms of diseases.
adj

semeiotics
The study of signs as an element of communication; the analysis of systems of communication; -- also called semiology; a theory of signs and symbols including as branches semantics pragmatics and syntactics.
n

semele
A daughter of Cadmus and by Zeus mother of Bacchus.
n

semen
The seed of plants; The seed or fecundating fluid of male animals; sperm. It is a white or whitish viscid fluid secreted by the testes characterized by the presence of spermatozoids to which it owes its generative power.
n

semeniferous
Seminiferous.
adj

semester
A period of six months; especially a term in a college or university which divides the year into two terms.
n

semi-
A prefix signifying half and sometimes partly or imperfectly; as semiannual half yearly; semitransparent imperfectly transparent.
misc

adj

semi-arian
A member of a branch of the Arians which did not acknowledge the Son to be consubstantial with the Father that is of the same substance but admitted him to be of a like substance with the Father not by nature but by a peculiar privilege; Of or pertaining to Semi-Arianism.

semi-arianism
The doctrines or tenets of the Semi-Arians.

n

semibarbarous
Half barbarous.
adj

semibreve
A note of half the time or duration of the breve; -- now usually called a whole note. It is the longest note in general use.
n

semibrief
A semibreve.
n

semibull
A bull issued by a pope in the period between his election and coronation.

semicircular

Half of a circumference.

semidiameter

semidiapente

n

Half or imperfectly transparent; translucent.
adj

semidiatessaron
An imperfect or diminished fourth.
n

semi-diesel
Designating an internal-combustion engine of a type resembling the Diesel engine in using as fuel heavy oil which is injected in a spray just before the end of the compression stroke and is fired without electrical ignition. The fuel is sprayed into an iron box (called a hot bulb or hot pot) opening into the combustion chamber and heated for ignition by a blast-lamp until the engine is running when it is ordinarily kept red hot by the heat of combustion.
adj

semiditone
A lesser third having its terms as 6 to 5; a hemiditone.
n

semidiurnal
Pertaining to or accomplished in half a day or twelve hours; occurring twice every day; Pertaining to or traversed in six hours or in half the time between the rising and setting of a heavenly body; as a semidiurnal arc.
adj

semidome
A roof or ceiling covering a semicircular room or recess or one of nearly that shape as the apse of a church a niche or the like. It is approximately the quarter of a hollow sphere.
n

semidouble
An office or feast celebrated with less solemnity than the double ones. See Double n. 8; Having the outermost stamens converted into petals while the inner ones remain perfect; -- said of a flower.
n

semifable
That which is part fable and part truth; a mixture of truth and fable.

semiflexed
Half bent.

adj

semiglutin
A peptonelike body insoluble in alcohol formed by boiling collagen or gelatin for a long time in water. Hemicollin a like body is also formed at the same time and differs from semiglutin by being partly soluble in alcohol.

Half or party historical.

adj

semimute
Having the faculty of speech but imperfectly developed or partially lost; A semimute person.
adj

seminal
Pertaining to containing or consisting of seed or semen; as the seminal fluid; Contained in seed; Holding the first place in a series of developed results or consequents; serving as a source or first principle; giving rise to related ideas or results; germinal; radical; primary; original; as seminal principles of generation; seminal virtue; a seminal discovery; A seed.
adj

seminality
The quality or state of being seminal.
n

seminar
A group of students engaged under the guidance of an instructor in original research in a particular line of study and in the exposition of the results by theses lectures etc.; -- formerly called also seminary now seldom used in this sense.
n

seminarian
A member of or one educated in a seminary; specifically an ecclesiastic educated for the priesthood in a seminary.
n

seminary
A piece of ground where seed is sown for producing plants for transplantation; a nursery; a seed plat; Hence the place or original stock whence anything is brought or produced; A place of education as a scool of a high grade an academy college or university; Seminal state; Fig.: A seed bed; a source; A Roman Catholic priest educated in a foreign seminary; a seminarist; Belonging to seed; seminal.
n

seminate
To sow; to spread; to propagate.

semination

n

semined
Thickly covered or sown as with seeds.

seminiferous
Seed-bearing; producing seed; pertaining to or connected with the formation of semen; as seminiferous cells or vesicles.
adj

seminific
Forming or producing seed or the male generative product of animals or of plants.
adj

seminification
Propagation from seed.
n

seminist
A believer in the old theory that the newly created being is formed by the admixture of the seed of the male with the supposed seed of the female.
n

seminoles
A tribe of Indians who formerly occupied Florida where some of them still remain. They belonged to the Creek Confideration.
n

seminose
A carbohydrate of the glucose group found in the thickened endosperm of certain seeds and extracted as yellow sirup having a sweetish-bitter taste.
n

seminude
Partially nude; half naked.
adj

seminymph
The pupa of insects which undergo only a slight change in passing to the imago state.

semipalmate
Having the anterior toes joined only part way down with a web; half-webbed; as a semipalmate bird or foot. See Illust. k under Aves.
adj

semiparabola
One branch of a parabola being terminated at the principal vertex of the curve.
n

semiped
A half foot in poetry.
n

semipedal
Containing a half foot.
adj

semi-pelagian
A follower of John Cassianus a French monk (died about 448) who modified the doctrines of Pelagius by denying human merit and maintaining the necessity of the Spirit's influence while on the other hand he rejected the Augustinian doctrines of election the inability of man to do good and the certain perseverance of the saints; Of or pertaining to the Semi-Pelagians or their tenets.
n

semi-pelagianism
The doctrines or tenets of the Semi-Pelagians.
n

semipellucid
Half clear or imperfectly transparent; as a semipellucid gem.

semipellucidity
The quality or state of being imperfectly transparent.
n

semipenniform
Half or partially penniform; as a semipenniform muscle.
adj

semipermanent
Half or partly permanent.
n

semiperspicuous
Half transparent; imperfectly clear; semipellucid.
adj

semiphlogisticated
Partially impregnated with phlogiston.
adj

semiplume
A feather which has a plumelike web with the shaft of an ordinary feather.
n

semiprecious
Somewhat precious; as semiprecious stones or metals. Used mostly of gemstones used in jewelry such as amethyst garnet or iolite which are sufficiently rare to have commercial value but are not considered as precious as are the diamond emerald and ruby.
adj

semiproof
Half proof; evidence from the testimony of a single witness.
n

semi-pupa
The young of an insect in a stage between the larva and pupa.
n

semiquadrate
An aspect of the planets when distant from each other the half of a quadrant or forty-five degrees or one sign and a half.
n

semiquaver
A note of half the duration of the quaver; -- now usually called a sixteenth note.
n

semiquintile
An aspect of the planets when distant from each other half of the quintile or thirty-six degrees.
n

semiradial
Half radial.
adj

semiradial-engine
See Radial engine above. - In or to a higher place; higher than; on or over the upper surface; over; -- opposed to below or beneath; Figuratively higher than; superior to in any respect; surpassing; beyond; higher in measure or degree than; as things above comprehension; above mean actions; conduct above reproach; Surpassing in number or quantity; more than; as above a hundred. (Passing into the adverbial sense. See Above adv. 4.); In a higher place; overhead; into or from heaven; as the clouds above; Earlier in order; higher in the same page; hence in a foregoing page; Higher in rank or power; as he appealed to the court above; More than; as above five hundred were present.
misc

semirecondite
Half hidden or half covered; said of the head of an insect when half covered by the shield of the thorax.
adj

semiring
One of the incomplete rings of the upper part of the bronchial tubes of most birds. The semirings form an essential part of the syrinx or musical organ of singing birds.
n

adj

semi-saxon
Half Saxon; -- specifically applied to the language intermediate between Saxon and English belonging to the period 1150-1250.

adj

semivowel

n

The purified fine hard parts of durum wheat derived mostly from the endosperm rounded by the attrition of the millstones -- used in cookery such as in the preparation of Italian pasta.

sen

n

senary
Of six; belonging to six; containing six.
adj

senate
An assembly or council having the highest deliberative and legislative functions; The upper and less numerous branch of a legislature in various countries as in France in the United States in most of the separate States of the United States and in some Swiss cantons; The governing body of the Universities of Cambridge and London; In some American colleges a council of elected students presided over by the president of the college to which are referred cases of discipline and matters of general concern affecting the students.
n

senator
A member of a senate; A member of the king's council; a king's councilor.
n

senatorial
Of or pertaining to a senator or a senate; becoming to a senator or a senate; as senatorial duties; senatorial dignity; Entitled to elect a senator or by senators; as the senatorial districts of a State.
adj

senatorially
In a senatorial manner.
adv

senatorian
Senatorial.
adj

senatorious
Senatorial.
adj

senatorship
The office or dignity of a senator.
n

senatusconsult
